basics.name: Michael A. Boateng
basics.label: Ph.D. Student in Electrical and Computer Engineering

work.name: Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT)
work.summary: Risk Assessment of Texas Grid Using AC SCOPF. Collaborating with ERCOT engineers on machine learning approaches for Security-Constrained AC Optimal Power Flow and greater than N-10 contingency analysis using real-world operational data from the Texas grid.
highlights: Enhancing grid reliability under large-scale system conditions (1000+ buses)
AC non-linearities incorporation into preventive SCOPF pipelines

work.name: Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL)
work.summary: End-to-End Learning for AC Feasibility Restoration in DCOPF. Designing LMP-preserving DCOPF-ACPF pipeline that learns DCOPF parameters and generator participation factors, computing pseudo-LMPs from AC-PF Jacobian sensitivities.
highlights: Implementing implicit-function gradients for end-to-end training
90% runtime reduction compared to conventional approaches
Fast feasibility restoration with smooth voltage-reactive power handling

work.name: Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL)
work.summary: Exploring DCOPF and ACPF Formulations for AC Feasibility. Engineered unified DCOPF→ACPF recovery pipeline combining four loss-aware DC models with AC feasibility restoration techniques.
highlights: 75% lower mean absolute error compared to traditional methods

work.name: AI Institute for Advances in Optimization (AI4OPT)
work.summary: Volt-VAR Optimization for Large-Scale Power Systems. Designed transmission-scale Volt/VAR Optimization framework that co-optimizes OLTC tap ratios and capacitor-bank modules under AC power-flow physics.
highlights: Extensive review of transmission-scale Volt/VAR methodologies

work.name: Georgia Institute of Technology
work.summary: Design Fundamentals (ECE 3011), Digital Design Lab (ECE 2031). Leading development of MPower Boards (MPBs) and advancing commercialization with Georgia Tech's Create-X program.
highlights: Created comprehensive lecture series and video guides
Developing physical, interactive power grid models for education
